facts.text: Civil Appeals No. 1026 to 1031 and 902 to 905 of 1963 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals No. 1026 to 1031, 902 to 905 of 1963. Appeals from the judgment and order dated 21st August, 1959 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgment and order dated 21st August 1959 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in specified Writ Petitions.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated 21st August, 1959 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 709, 710, 721 of 1957, 466, 1160 and 1426 of 1958, 1244, 125G and 1257 of 1957 and 1205 of 1957.

facts.text: Central Government issued notification on June 6, 1957 under s. 3(3A) of Essential Commodities Act 1955 to control rise in prices and prevent hoarding of rice and paddy in Andhra Pradesh among other states for three months.

anchor.surface_text: On June 6, 1957, a numberification was issued by the Central Government under s. 3 3A  of the Essential Commodities Act, No. 10 of 1955,  hereinafter referred to as the Act . The numberification said that in the opinion of the Central Government it was necessary to companytrol the rise in prices and prevent the hoarding of rice and paddy in the States and Union territories.

facts.text: On July 31, 1957, Central Government delegated powers under s.3 of the Act relating to rice and paddy in Andhra Pradesh to Shri K. S. Krishnan, Deputy Director Food, Vijayawada for three months.

anchor.surface_text: On July 31, 1957, the Central Government made another numberification directing that the powers companyferred on it by s. 3 of the Act to make orders providing for the matters specified in cl.  f  and for the matters specified in cls.  h ,  i  and  j , insofar as they relate to cl.  f  of sub-s.  2  of s. 3 in relation to stocks of ,rice and paddy held in any locality in the State of Andhra Pradesh shall be exercisable also by Shri K. S. Krishnan, Deputy Director  Food , Government of India, Vijayawada.

facts.text: On July 31, 1957, Central Government authorized Shri K. S. Krishnan to determine average market rate of rice and paddy in Andhra Pradesh under s.3(3A)(c).

anchor.surface_text: Further on the same day the Central Government issued another numberification by which in pursuance of cl. of sub-s.  3A  of s. 3 of the Act, the Central Government authorised the said Shri Krishnan to determine the average market rate of rice and paddy prevailing in any locality in the State of Andhra Pradesh.

facts.text: On August 20, 1957, Shri Krishnan directed rice millers in Tadepalligudem to sell certain quantities and kinds of rice to Assistant Director Food at price per s.3(3A).

anchor.surface_text: On August 20, 1957, Shri Krishnan in exercise of the powers companyferred upon him by the numberifications mentioned above directed a number of rice millers in Tadepalligudem to sell to the Assistant Director  Food , Government of India, certain quantities and kinds of rice at the price calculated in accordance with cls.  iii  and of sub-s.  3A  of S. 3 of the Act.

facts.text: Rice ordered on August 20, 1957 was delivered to Assistant Director Food up to September 13, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence of this order, such quantities of rice as were ordered to be sold were delivered to the Assistant Director  Food  on various dates upto September 13, 1957.

facts.text: Prices for rice procured under orders from August 20, 1957 were fixed by Shri Krishnan in September 1957; appellants dispute that prices were properly fixed under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that prices are claimed to have been fixed by Shri Krishnan for the rice procured under the orders passed on August 20, 1957 and on subsequent dates in accordance with the provisions of the Act in September 1957. The appellants dispute that the prices have been properly fixed under the provisions of the Act

facts.text: On September 14, 1957, Central Government issued notification fixing maximum price for rice and paddy over 10 maunds in Krishna, West Godavari, East Godavari districts under s.3(2)(c).

anchor.surface_text: On September 14, 1957, the Central Government issued a numberification fixing the, maximum price at which rice and paddy of various kinds was to be sold in any one transaction of more than ten maunds in the districts of Krishna, West Godavari and East Godavari in the State of Andhra Pradesh under cl.  c  of sub-s.  2  of S. 3 of the Act.

facts.text: Deputy Director made requisitions of rice from appellants between September 14, 1957 and December 29, 1957 and paid maximum prices fixed by Central Government.

anchor.surface_text: Following this fixation the Deputy Director made requisitions between September 14, 1957 and December 29, 1957 of different varieties of rice from various appellants under the powers vested in him by the numberifications already referred to under cl.  f  of sub-s.  2  of s. 3 of the Act and fixed prices therefore. He claims to have fixed price therefore in accordance with S. 3  3A  of the Act, though actually the maximum prices fixed by the Central Government were paid.

facts.text: Appellants contend notifications and actions for second period violate Articles 14, 19(1)(f) and (g), 31(2) of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the appellants with respect to this period is that the numberification fixing price and the action taken thereunder is hit by Art. 14, Art. 19 1   f  and  g  and Art. 31 2  of the Constitution and therefore they are entitled to the rates prevailing in the market at the time.

facts.text: On December 30, 1957, Central Government issued notification refixing lower maximum prices for rice and paddy in Krishna, West Godavari, East Godavari and Guntur districts after new rice crop came into market.

anchor.surface_text: On December 30, 1957, after the new rice crop had companye into the market, the Central Government issued another numberification by which maximum prices were refixed in the districts of Krishna, West Godavari, East Godavari and Guntur in the State of Andhra Pradesh under s. 3  2   c  of the Act.

facts.text: Deputy Director procured more rice from appellants after December 30, 1957 at maximum prices fixed on that date.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter there was more pro- curement of rice by the Deputy Director  food  from the various appellants and he claims to have fixed prices therefore in accordance with the provisions of s. 3 3A  of the Act, though actually he paid the maximum price fixed in the numberification of December 30, 1957.

facts.text: Appellants filed writ petitions in Andhra Pradesh High Court challenging price fixations and seeking directions for fair prices based on market rates.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants therefore along with a large number of other rice millers filed writ petitions before the High Court. With respect to the first period, the appellants prayed that the Deputy Director be directed to fix the price of rice requisitioned from them at the rate calculated with reference to the average of the market rate prevailing at Tadepallegudem during the period of three months immediately preceding the date of the numberification

facts.text: High Court rejected appellants' contentions and dismissed writ petitions with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected all the companytentions raised on behalf of the, appellants and dismissed the writ petitions with companyts.

facts.text: High Court granted certificates for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then applied for and obtained certificates from the High Court and that is how the matter has companye up before us.

facts.text: New rice crop came into market from November 1957, leading to price reduction on December 30, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Now the reason for reduction of prices on December 30 was that the new crop came into the market from November 1957. It is a well-known economic fact that prices fall whenever the new crop companyes into the market.

facts.text: Vijayawada is at a distance of 80 miles from Tadepalligudem.

anchor.surface_text: which it is said is At a distance of 80 miles from Tadepellagudem.

facts.text: Deputy Director used published rates from Vijayawada to calculate average market rates for Tadepalligudem, adjusting for transport and quality.

anchor.surface_text: Now what the Deputy Director did was to take into account the rates published in Vijavawada, which it is said is At a distance of 80 miles from Tadepellagudem. It is however number disputed that there is numbernearer locality where published figures are available.

facts.text: Prices at Tadepalligudem are generally lower than at Vijayawada by about Rs. 1.20 per average for same quality rice, per State Marketing Officer compilation.

anchor.surface_text: We may also refer to the rates companypiled by the State Marketing Officer, Andhra Pradesh which were placed before the High Court on behalf of the respondents. These rates were companypiled before the numberification of June 6, 1957 in a free market and show that there is a difference in price between Tadepallegudem and Vijayawada and prices at Tadepallegudem arc generally lower than the prices at Vijavawada and on an average, the price at Tadepallegudem is about Rs. 1.20 less than at Vijayawada for the same quality of rice.

facts.text: Nallarlu, Garikulu and Akkulu rice varieties procured; Deputy Director treated Nallarlu and Garikulu as slightly inferior to Akkulu and adjusted prices down by Rs.1.50.

anchor.surface_text: What he did was to take into account the published figures of Vijayawada and then make adjustments taking into account the transport charges and the quality of rice procured, for in two cases the rice procured by him was number quoted in the figures available in Vijayawada. It, however, appears that these two varieties of rice procured are slightly inferior to the rice for which the prices were available in Vijayawada

facts.text: Appellants contend Deputy Director should have used prices from their account books as published figures.

anchor.surface_text: It is however urged that the words published figures in cl.  iv  would include even the prices in the accounts books of the appellants for these prices must be taken to be published prices inasmuch as the accounts books used to be shown to sales tax and income-tax authorities and the entries therein were therefore published.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that ss.3 and 4 of the Act do not violate Art.19(1)(f) and (g).

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, for the reasons given in Harishanker Baglascase,  2  which were accepted in Bhanamal Gulzarilals case,  2  we hold that ss. 3 and 4 of the Act are number hit by Art. 19 1   f  and  g  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds price control orders do not violate Art.14 as they apply to surplus rice producing districts.

anchor.surface_text: The short answer to this companytention is that the districts to which the orders applied are surplus rice producing districts in the State of Andhra Pradesh and that is why the orders were companyfined to those districts.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Act provides principles for compensation under Art.31(2) via fair prices in s.3.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 1  provides for availability of essential companymodities at fair prices. So the first principle which the Act provides is that the price fixed should be fair, and that involves in it all factors which have to be taken into account in fixing a fair price.

issues.text: Whether sections 3 and 4 of the Essential Commodities Act violate Article 19(1)(f) and (g) of the Constitution by imposing unreasonable restrictions on the right to acquire, hold and dispose of property and to carry on trade or business?

anchor.surface_text: We shall first take up the contention based on cls. f and g of Art. 19 1 . It is said that the provisions of the Act impose unreasonable restrictions on the right to acquire, hold and dispose of property, and to practice any profession, or to carry on any occupation. trade or business.

issues.text: Whether the price control orders violate Article 14 of the Constitution by applying only to certain surplus rice producing districts in Andhra Pradesh?

anchor.surface_text: The next attack on the orders passed under the Act is that they violate Art. 14 of the Constitution inasmuch as they relate only to certain districts in the State of Andhra Pradesh and not to others. The short answer to this contention is that the districts to which the orders applied are surplus rice producing districts

issues.text: Whether the Essential Commodities Act provides principles and manner for determining compensation under Article 31(2) for requisitioned rice?

anchor.surface_text: The next contention is based on Art. 31 2 . That article provides that no property shall be compulsorily acquired or requisitioned save for a public purpose and save by authority of a law which provides for compensation for the property so acquired or requisitioned and either fixes the amount of the compensation or specifies the principles on which, and the manner in which, the compensation is to be determined

issues.text: Whether procurement of rice after December 30, 1957 at reduced maximum prices under the new notification applies to stocks purchased by appellants between September 14 and December 29, 1957?

anchor.surface_text: Then we come to the contention that the procurement which was made after December 29, 1957, when the price was reduced by the notification of December 30, 1957, as compared with the price fixed in the notification dated September 14, 1957, should have been in accordance with the notification of September 14, 1957 at any rate insofar as the rice purchased by the appellants between September 14 and December 29, 1957 was concerned.

issues.text: Whether the prices fixed by the Deputy Director for rice procured between August 20 and September 13, 1957 were in accordance with section 3(3A) of the Essential Commodities Act?
Whether the Deputy Director was required to first attempt agreement under section 3(3A)(iii)(a) before fixing price under clause (c)?
Whether 'published figures' under section 3(3A)(iv) include prices recorded in private account books of the appellants?

anchor.surface_text: It is however urged that the words published figures in cl. iv would include even the prices in the accounts books of the appellants for these prices must be taken to be published prices inasmuch as the accounts books used to be shown to sales tax and income-tax authorities and the entries therein were therefore published.

issues.text: Whether the Deputy Director properly determined the average market rate using published figures from Vijayawada (neighbouring locality) with adjustments for transport and quality?
Whether prior notice and opportunity of hearing was required before fixing prices under section 3(3A)(c)?

anchor.surface_text: With respect to the first period, the appellants prayed that the Deputy Director be directed to fix the price of rice requisitioned from them at the rate calculated with reference to the average of the market rate prevailing at Tadepallegudem during the period of three months immediately preceding the date of the notification after giving notice and opportunity to the appellants

issues.text: Whether the finality clause in section 3(3A)(iv) precludes judicial review under Article 226?
Whether the power under the Act to impose price controls is arbitrary and without limitation, violating Article 19(1)?

anchor.surface_text: The notifications issued by the Central Government fixing maximum prices were attacked on the ground that the power vested by the Act in the Central Government to impose controls was an arbitrary power without limitation and was therefore an unreasonable restriction and hit by Art. 19 1 .

holdings.text: Sections 3 and 4 of the Essential Commodities Act are not hit by Article 19(1)(f) and (g) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, for the reasons given in Harishanker Baglascase,  2  which were accepted in Bhanamal Gulzarilals case,  2  we hold that ss. 3 and 4 of the Act are number hit by Art. 19 1   f  and  g  of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows binding precedents in Harishankar Bagla and Bhanamal Gulzarimal cases upholding similar provisions.

holdings.text: The price control orders do not violate Article 14 as the affected districts form a reasonable class of surplus rice producing areas.

anchor.surface_text: The short answer to this companytention is that the districts to which the orders applied are surplus rice producing districts in the State of Andhra Pradesh and that is why the orders were companyfined to those districts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Surplus districts form a distinct class justifying differential treatment to control prices effectively.

holdings.text: The Essential Commodities Act satisfies Article 31(2) by providing the principle of fair price under s.3(1) and manner under ss.3(3) and 3A.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 1  provides for availability of essential companymodities at fair prices. So the first principle which the Act provides is that the price fixed should be fair, and that involves in it all factors which have to be taken into account in fixing a fair price.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory provisions indicate fair price as principle considering relevant factors and specify manner of determination.

holdings.text: Procurement after December 30, 1957 at reduced prices under the new notification is valid, even for rice purchased between September 14 and December 29, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the companytention of the appellants that rice procured by them between September 14 and December 29 should have been requisitioned at least at prices fixed by the numberification of September 14 must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Price reduction mirrors free market due to new crop; prevents dual pricing; aligns with fair price objective under s.3(1).

holdings.text: Prices fixed by the Deputy Director for rice procured between August 20 and September 13, 1957 were in accordance with s.3(3A) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention that the prices fixed by the Deputy Director were number in accordance with the provisions of the law must therefore be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deputy Director complied with s.3(3A)(c) and (iv) using nearest published figures with proper adjustments; finality clause supports.

holdings.text: Where no controlled price exists, the Deputy Director may directly fix price under s.3(3A)(iii)(c) without attempting agreement under (a) or (b).

anchor.surface_text: Therefore we are of opinion that this is a case where. sub-cl. c applied as there was numbercontrolled price during the relevant period.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-clauses (a) and (b) apply only where controlled price fixed; clauses complementary; 'if any' indicates condition precedent.

holdings.text: 'Published figures' under s.3(3A)(iv) means publicly available figures like newspapers, not private account books.

anchor.surface_text: The words published figures must be given their ordinary meaning. That is that the figures should be publicised in some way, say, for example, in newspapers, or on the Radio or in any other manner

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinary meaning requires general publication to public; account books not generally available.

holdings.text: Deputy Director properly determined average market rate using Vijayawada published figures (nearest available) with adjustments for transport and quality.

anchor.surface_text: Now what the Deputy Director did was to take into account the rates published in Vijavawada, which it is said is At a distance of 80 miles from Tadepellagudem. It is however number disputed that there is numbernearer locality where published figures are available.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Vijayawada nearest with published data; adjustments reasonable per evidence and economic facts; supported by State Marketing Officer data.

holdings.text: Finality clause in s.3(3A)(iv) does not oust High Court jurisdiction under Art.226 but limits interference absent serious injustice from statutory disregard.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicitly preserves jurisdiction but emphasizes non-interference unless clear violation causing injustice.

holdings.text: No prior notice or hearing required before fixing price under s.3(3A)(c) in absence of controlled price.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedure of agreement/controlled price inapplicable; direct fixation under (c) per statute; natural justice not mandated.
